title: Crippling chronic illness saw woman miss 5 years of school and lose several jobs
text:

A woman has told how a crippling chronic illness has saw her miss five years of school and lose a number of jobs.

Hollie Buxton, 21, has ME, also known as chronic fatigue syndrome, which she developed after being bullied when she was nine.

She missed five years of school as a result of the condition, which isn't eased by resting.

When her illness flares up, she can barely move in the mornings

The condition has resulted in her losing several jobs, Bristol Live reports .

Hollie, of Bristol, said: “I was diagnosed when I was 10. It started when I was getting massively fatigued and I had a lot of sickness. I thought it was a bug at first, but I continued to get worse.

(Image: Bristol Live WS)

“These symptoms went on for several months before I was officially diagnosed, and it was a continuous cycle of going back and forth to the doctors."

Hollie missed year four to year nine of school because “it was impossible,” she said.

She continued: “The reason for my illness was because I was really badly bullied.

“If something stressful and traumatic is happening to you it can inflict chronic fatigue syndrome.

“The bullying started in year three, but in year four it took a massive turn and this is when I left because my health deteriorated. It was a horrendous time."

She describes not being able to move and says ‘it was a horrendous time’.

She said: “I couldn’t move unaided. It hit me like a ton of bricks at the beginning. I couldn't leave the house for several months, I couldn’t eat, I was skin and bones."

During the five years Hollie wasn’t at school she didn’t experience many ‘ups’ and her mental health suffered.

“I didn’t have many good days, but what kept me going was education. I had so many aspirations and goals in life so I tried to keep my mind occupied with these thoughts,” she said.

“During the five years, I had some hospital education, but it was more playing games and I didn’t feel it was an education, and I felt myself becoming more tired because I put all my energy into something that wasn’t ever going to help me."

(Image: Bristol Live WS)

In 2012, Hollie got in contact with Bridge Learning Campus secondary who ‘helped and supported’ her condition, however she said she ‘struggled to cope’ as the bullying continued.

“My chronic fatigue never stabilised," she said.

“So I pretty much only did year 10 and year 11 full time. I had some days where I really struggled physically but I got my head down. I wanted education so badly.

“I’ve always been academically driven so I really tried my best and I was pleased with what I got, I left school with A’s, B’s and C’s.

In March 2018, after her A levels, she plunged in and went to work full time in a nursery, but the physicality of the job resulted in her becoming incredibly ill three months later.

“I had to leave because I could not keep up with consistency. One day I would be in, the next I wasn’t, I was stuck in the vicious cycle. So I had to take myself out of this situation.

During this time, Hollie developed glandular fever, which heightened her chronic fatigue, making any activity impossible.

After a well rested few months, Hollie felt positive and ready to embark into a new job field.

She said: “I was in a bit of boat where I didn’t want to give up, and I needed something where I could find my feet again.

At the end of August 2019, Hollie was offered a part time job as a pharmacy assistant which she started to enjoy.

“However, the second week I had a massive chronic fatigue flare up, I couldn’t even sit up on my own, and I lost my job."

Without notice, she received a letter terminating her contract, Hollie claims.

“The communication from the pharmacy was awful. The week after my flare up, I received a letter from them saying that they were terminating my contract,” she said.

“Before I received the letter, I saw my job advertised online. I was panicking so much because this was my job, my stability, my finance.

“I felt I was sacked because I had an illness. They didn’t let me go back and try again, they didn’t give me a chance.

“My manager told me he could of made adjustments for me, if he knew I had a chronic illness, but he did nothing."

Hollie is now out of work and is searching for a job which will accommodate her condition.

“I am so passionate and motivated and all I want is to do well. I just want to be a job that I can cope with, with an understanding team.

“It really does get me down because I can’t control it, but I am determined to come out stronger."

Hollie describes a flare up as ‘the flu, times by 10, and then five all-nighters in a row’.

She said: “When I have a flare up, I wake up and I cannot move. It is not just tiredness, but exhaustion, I can barely lift my head.

“I either slept and slept and slept or I would never sleep because I was in too much pain.

Some of the main symptoms of the codition are sleep problems, muscle or joint, and headaches , a sore throat or sore glands that aren't swollen

Most people find overexercising makes their symptoms worse.

The severity of symptoms can vary from day to day, or even within a day.
description: When Hollie Buxton's ME flare's up, she can barely move when she wakes up, and the condition has resulted in her losing several jobs
